title: Truth Gaming LF Coach
body:
Hello everyone,

Truth Gaming are currently looking for a permanent coach for the main team!

The position requires you to be able to keep completely up to date with patch notes, and figuring out what would/could be strong in that patch. Also, will need to be competent with doing solid draft phases.

If interested, just chuck me a DM detailing your coaching experience, and what you believe you can bring to the organisation!

replies.body:
You are not paying for the position. Why are you asking for so much? Exprienced personel? Willing to bring in and pour so much into the org? And for what? Did you ever state why it would benefit the person? No? Never thought why it would be "worth their while"? 

When these sorts of "advertising" pop up. Any talents worth their salt, would understand that the person incharge of the org is a dreamer. Lacking so much knowledge on management structures. 

Every time Truth gaming have put up a recruitment thread, they're asking for a professional level of commitment, while not paying a dim. Or, state any beneficial reasons why it would be an advantage to work for the org.

If no one is getting paid, then it is a hobby. If it is a hobby then you will have different levels of dedication. And on this factor of difference, group usually fall apart; If the "employees" are being treated the same as a profit organisation. Since there is no hierarchy of salary to aim for, it is not worth while to improve your standing within the org. The title come with responsibilities, and doing it all for free is a pain to life and a joke. 

To be frank, this truth gaming is destined for failure.

The team essentially is a hobby. Truth isn't in the OCS or OPL, and we just compete in amateur tournaments. There is no money involved for players or staff, and there isn't a reason for there to be considering it's purely amateur competition at the current point in time. 

Currently, the team acts as a space for us to learn about teamplay, improve on macro and micro strategy, and for fun. I don't speak for everyone, but I'm pretty sure a few of us would like to play in the OCS at some point. Amateur tournaments and teams act as a sort of "scouting grounds" outside of SoloQ for that.

In terms of "experience", he's just asking people to detail what past coaching experience they have. They don't necessarily need to have any, it's just to gauge whether both parties would be able to work together well or not. You wouldn't submit a resume without listing where you've worked in the past, right? Same concept, minus the job and getting paid part. Coaches aren't expected to be Challenger, commit 40 hours a week + overtime, and drop everything for the team. We just want someone that knows what they're talking about to give us a hand with drafting better and maybe working on some mistakes for an hour or two after a week of scrims. 

If someone wants to be paid for the position, then we'd just look for a paid coach. This is a position for someone that wants to have some fun and work on their coaching skills, learning some stuff on the way. No harm done if no one wants to, no harm done if someone does. It is what it is.

What you've said about the **extent **of a coach's responsibilty and abilities; It's missing from the context of the thread. 

From an outsider point of view, it seem you guys are asking for a qualify "Proven working background" person to take the postion. If it was writen and clearly point out the range of the role's duties, it would not appeared as a highly qualify position. But more to the side of, "lets work together and go up in a casual/low pressure environment".

It's entry level, like when you do work experience to put on your resume so that you can move up to OCS in the future.

The thread itself is not well defined. From just reading the context it's seem to imply a "ready to go" experience is necessary position. 

In many ways "atleast to me" it's suggested that the applicants is required to have a wealth of knowledge, and is able to handle big responsibilities. "I've read up on what it would take to become a head coach, and it is not to be underestimated. The coach would have to forgo many leisures to ensures things are going well. Aswell as having a high degree of ability to assimilate rapport". The way this thread was context, it is in no way an intern friendly position. 

The poster should've put what is required from the applicants. ASWELL as introduce the organisation and explain reasons why working for the org would benefit the person. Perhave give a little insight on how things are now, and a realistic "direction" they would like to move toward. This will give a sense of seriousness from the ORG, and that times spend in the org will not be aimless.
